documents.t: Enhancing SAP AVC for Real-World Product Complexity

To get started with mdVC, ensure that SAP AVC is properly licensed, activated, and configured in your S/4HANA system. mdVC is an add-on that extends AVC ‚Äî not a standalone module ‚Äî so AVC must already be operational.
Essentially, mdVC is plugged in AVC technically in the BADI enhancement spot vchhles_core.

Master Data-Driven Variant Configuration (mdVC) is a lightweight but powerful add-on framework that extends SAP S/4HANA Advanced Variant Configuration (AVC) ‚Äî designed specifically for complex configuration scenarios where standard AVC tooling reaches its limits.
documents.s: Enhancing SAP AVC for Real-World Product Complexity
Enhancing SAP AVC for Real-World Product Complexity

documents.t: To get started with mdVC, ensure that SAP AVC is properly licensed, activated, and configured in your S/4HANA system. mdVC is an add-on that extends AVC ‚Äî not a standalone module ‚Äî so AVC must already be operational. Once mdVC is installed, you can verify the installation under your system's installed software components: (Navigate to: System > Status > Details) note We are actively working toward full Clean Core compliance. In some areas, stable and officially released interfaces from SAP are still missing, which currently prevents full clean-core architecture across all use cases. Full Clean Core compliance will follow as soon as the required released interfaces from SAP are available. As of now, the add-on is structured into: /MXP/VCHA Tier 1 ‚Äì fully Clean Core‚Äìcompliant components /MXP/VCHA2 Tier 2 ‚Äì some components with limited core modification (currently being refactored)

Essentially, mdVC is plugged in AVC technically in the BADI enhancement spot vch_hl_es_core. The BADI provides filter values for: configuration_context Context, which is calling the variant configuration cfg_object_type Name of database table for object cfg_object_key Key of configurable object plant Plant which can be used to determine the actual implementation and whether mdVC is to be used for a specific use case or not.
Usually, when using mdVC we recommend to keep the model lean and model complex logic and dependencies in mdVC exclusively.

Create a BADI implementation for BADI vch_hl_es_core-vch_hl_post_validate_assign and maintain (if required) appropriate filter values. In your newly created implementation class, navigate to if_vch_hl_post_validate_assign~assign_values. This is where we call implementations done in mdVC.
The spot if_vch_hl_post_validate_assign~assign_values is called from AVC after executing and validating the configuration model (which is usually very lean as already mentioned).

The BADI implementation is the glue and is intended to define the behavior and flow of mdVC. Every call looks the same. In your implementation class follow this pattern: /mxp/vcha_cl_va_engine=>factory( i_badi_implementation = me i_explosion_date = ref #( explosion_date ) i_hierarchy = ref #( hierarchy ) i_characteristics = ref #( characteristics ) i_values = ref #( values ) i_bill_of_materials = ref #( bill_of_materials ) i_assign_by_value = ref #( assign_by_value ) i_assign_by_key = ref #( assign_by_key ) i_unassign = ref #( unassign ) )->process( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_composite( value #( "task list, one after each other ( new zcl_your_task( ) ) "task implementation(s) to be replaced ) ) ). The class /mxp/vcha_cl_va_engine is the entry point to mdVC. All mdVC specific logic is wrapped within the engine. This is the only touch-point with the AVC BADI implementation. The engine is for holding/accessing all information of the configuration, and for executing a so called task (which can be a simple or a composite task) - controlling the behavior. In the example above, zcl_your_task is the name of a class implementing the mdVC interface for a single task, where data can be read, changed, validated, error messages issued, trace logs written, ...

mdVC comes, from a framwork side, with a predefined set of usable tasks. They do not contain any logic and are intentend only to define the the execution flow. For actual logic, see Connectors or simply create your task inheriting from /MXP/VCHA_CL_VA_TASK_SIMPLE. Below you will find the usable tasks you can use to define the behavior of mdVC, highlighted. Simple Task‚Äã This type of task is ready for redefinition in Z and thus adding some logic in ABAP. This task is basically a single task, which has exactly one purpose, like validation, or like determination of some sophisticated value. In most of the cases simply inherit from /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_simple. You are forced to redefine the method /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute which is called from the framework and gives access to all the parts mentioned in the sub-headings below. Here you will find an example implementation, which can just linked class zcl_your_task definition public create public inheriting from /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_simple. public section. methods /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute redefinition. endclass. class zcl_your_task implementation. method /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute. "get THICKNESS data(l_thickness) = i_engine->m_container->get_characteristic_by_name( i_instance_id = i_engine->m_container->m_root_instance_id i_cstic_name = 'THICKNESS' ). data(l_thickness_val) = i_engine->m_container->get_assigned_value_for_cstic( l_thickness->key ). "get THICKNESS2 data(l_thickness2) = i_engine->m_container->get_characteristic_by_name( i_instance_id = i_engine->m_container->m_root_instance_id i_cstic_name = 'THICKNESS2' ). data(l_thickness2_val) = i_engine->m_container->get_assigned_value_for_cstic( l_thickness2->key ). "write max of THICKNESS or THICKNESS2 to THICKNESS_MAX i_engine->m_container->assign_value( value #( key = i_engine->m_container->get_characteristic_by_name( i_instance_id = i_engine->m_container->m_root_instance_id i_cstic_name = 'THICKNESS_MAX' )->key value_float = cond #( when l_thickness_val->value_float_min > l_thickness2_val->value_float_min then l_thickness_val->value_float_min else l_thickness2_val->value_float_min ) ) ). endmethod. endclass. note Most of the time in custom coding, we want access characteristics by its NAME. That's why it's needed to call get_characteristic_by_name. If not returned, the characteristic was not found within the configuration and indicates an model error. Value Get/Set‚Äã Setting and getting values can be done with using methods of interface /mxp/vcha_if_va_container. The actual Container holds all the information about the context, characteristics in the configuration and all the values (assigned or not). You can simply access the container with i_engine->m_container. For a value get/set example, please see above. info There are different types of "assignment types": user input, determination, ... Most of the time, user input has priority before determination. So if needed, handle the assignment type poperly (/mxp/vcha_if_va_container=>c_assignment_types-user_input). Influence UI‚Äã The different UI facets in AVC context read-only hidden mandatory value exclusion can be read and set via methods of interface /mxp/vcha_if_va_session_bridge. The so called session bridge provides access to the AVC session and allows to influence the UI. You can simply access the session with i_engine->m_session. Please find an example for hiding some characteristic based on values in configuration below: class zcl_my_task definition public create public inheriting from /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_simple. public section. methods /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute redefinition. protected section. private section. endclass. class zcl_my_task implementation. method /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute. "get product type value data(l_product_type) = i_engine->m_container->get_assigned_value_for_cstic( i_engine->m_container->get_characteristic_by_name( i_instance_id = i_engine->m_container->m_root_instance_id i_cstic_name = 'PRODUCT_TYPE' )->key ). "determine whether to hide attribute and hide it or not i_engine->m_session->set_cstic_hidden( i_key = i_engine->m_container->get_characteristic_by_name( i_instance_id = i_engine->m_container->m_root_instance_id i_cstic_name = 'LENGTH' )->key i_is_hidden = cond #( when l_product_type->value_string = 'COIL' then if_vch_hl_post_validate_assign=>gc_boolean-true ) ). endmethod. endclass. note This is not a complete example. Eventually already assigned values needs to be unassigned, too. This example only focuses on UI influence. Log‚Äã In your implementation you can add any messages (of any type) to the log by calling methods of interface /mxp/vcha_if_log. As the log is tied to the session you can access the log for the session via i_engine->m_session->m_log. Please find an example for adding some custom messages below: class zcl_my_task definition public create public inheriting from /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_simple. public section. methods /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute redefinition. protected section. private section. endclass. class zcl_my_task implementation. method /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute. message e899(v1) with 'test message' into data(l_message_text). i_engine->m_session->m_log->add_sy_message( ). endmethod. endclass. info Error messages do not result in a erroneous status automatically. As for the example above, it only adds the message to the log. Please see section Status to learn how to set status accordingly (or derive whether there are error messages). In AVC, the messages will be displayed in the standard message popover: Trace‚Äã Similar to the Log handling, additional infos can be written to the standard AVC trace. It is intentended to provide additional hints to understand complex situations. The trace can be accessed with methods of interface /mxp/vcha_if_trace. As the trace too is tied to the session you can access the trace for the session via i_engine->m_session->m_trace. class zcl_my_task definition create public inheriting from /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_simple. public section. methods /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute redefinition. protected section. private section. endclass. class zcl_my_task implementation. method /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute. message e899(v1) with 'test trace message' into data(l_message_text). i_engine->m_session->m_trace->add_sy_message( ). endmethod. endclass. The result will look like this: tip For hints which are again very complex to give, call method /mxp/vcha_if_trace->is_active( ) to check if the user needs a detail analysis. Status‚Äã In your implementation you can influence the status of the configuration by calling methods of interface /mxp/vcha_if_status. As the status is tied to the session you can access the status for the session via i_engine->m_session->m_status. Please find an example for influencing the status below: class zcl_my_task definition create public inheriting from /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_simple. public section. methods /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute redefinition. protected section. private section. endclass. class zcl_my_task implementation. method /mxp/vcha_if_va_task~execute. data(l_thickness) = i_engine->m_container->get_assigned_value_for_cstic( i_engine->m_container->get_characteristic_by_name( i_instance_id = i_engine->m_container->m_root_instance_id i_cstic_name = 'THICKNESS' )->key ). if l_thickness is not bound or l_thickness->value_float_min <= 0. i_engine->m_session->m_status->set_incomplete( ). else. i_engine->m_session->m_status->set_released( ). endif. endmethod. endclass. Best practice‚Äã Most of the time, the user expects an error message when the configuration is "Incomplete". Our best practice is, to use a Composite Task as top level task, issue error messages (or not) within a simple task and then add the generic class /mxp/vcha_cl_va_log_to_status as the last one for the composite task. The class simply looks for any error message in the log. If there is any, the status "Incomplete" is set. If not, the Status "Released" is set. Quite simple implementation, but in most of the cases this is the required behavior. Here is an example for our initial behavior defintion within the BADI implementation. /mxp/vcha_cl_va_engine=>factory( i_badi_implementation = me i_explosion_date = ref #( explosion_date ) i_hierarchy = ref #( hierarchy ) i_characteristics = ref #( characteristics ) i_values = ref #( values ) i_bill_of_materials = ref #( bill_of_materials ) i_assign_by_value = ref #( assign_by_value ) i_assign_by_key = ref #( assign_by_key ) i_unassign = ref #( unassign ) )->process( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_composite( value #( "task list, one after each other ( new zcl_your_task( ) ) "task implementation(s) to be replaced ( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_log_to_status( ) ) "evaluates error messages and sets status ) ) ). Composite Task‚Äã A composite task is basically just another task which can be either directly given to the engine, or stacked in another composite task. It contains one to many tasks (simple or composite), and executes it sequentially one after the other. Using composite tasks, we can define quite complex behaviors. /mxp/vcha_cl_va_engine=>factory( i_badi_implementation = me i_explosion_date = ref #( explosion_date ) i_hierarchy = ref #( hierarchy ) i_characteristics = ref #( characteristics ) i_values = ref #( values ) i_bill_of_materials = ref #( bill_of_materials ) i_assign_by_value = ref #( assign_by_value ) i_assign_by_key = ref #( assign_by_key ) i_unassign = ref #( unassign ) )->process( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_composite( value #( "task list, one after each other ( new zcl_initialize_some_things( ) ) "task implementation(s) to be replaced ( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_composite( value #( ( new zcl_do_something( ) ) ( new zcl_do_something2( ) ) ) ) ) ( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_log_to_status( ) ) "evaluates error messages and sets status ) ) ). Thus this example does not make much too sense, as the zcl_do_something and zcl_do_something2 could have been easily added to the first composite task too, it shows the idea behind. There are use-cases like we need to do things in a loop, where stacking composite tasks makes sense. Important to know: Any task can be added, as long as it implements the mdVC task interface /mxp/vcha_if_va_trace. Settler Task‚Äã A settler task is a special implementation of a composite task and essentially repeats the contained tasks as long as the values in the container reach stability. An Example: CharacteristicA influences CharacteristicB and vice versa. As soon as one Characteristic changes we need to repeat the other. As long as the values reach stability (do not influence each other anymore). A settler task simply executes every contained task sequentially, just like any other composite task, but does that in a loop. /mxp/vcha_cl_va_engine=>factory( i_badi_implementation = me i_explosion_date = ref #( explosion_date ) i_hierarchy = ref #( hierarchy ) i_characteristics = ref #( characteristics ) i_values = ref #( values ) i_bill_of_materials = ref #( bill_of_materials ) i_assign_by_value = ref #( assign_by_value ) i_assign_by_key = ref #( assign_by_key ) i_unassign = ref #( unassign ) )->process( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_composite( value #( "task list, one after each other ( new zcl_initialize_some_things( ) ) "task implementation(s) to be replaced ( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_task_settler( value #( "repeat until values reaches stability ( new zcl_calc_b_based_on_a( ) ) ( new zcl_calc_a_based_on_b( ) ) ) ) ) ( new /mxp/vcha_cl_va_log_to_status( ) ) "evaluates error messages and sets status ) ) ). When using CDS views and defining dependencies between characteristics with view attributes, a task settler normally is needed as the cds view will get executed as long as all dependencies were resolved.

Master Data-Driven Variant Configuration (mdVC) is a lightweight but powerful add-on framework that extends SAP S/4HANA Advanced Variant Configuration (AVC) ‚Äî designed specifically for complex configuration scenarios where standard AVC tooling reaches its limits. Built by configuration experts from metalsXP, mdVC addresses a common challenge: while AVC offers a constraint-based modeling approach, real-world business logic ‚Äî particularly in industries like metals, machinery, and industrial manufacturing ‚Äî often requires more than what constraints, variant tables, and procedures can express. mdVC bridges that gap.
documents.s: Enhancing SAP AVC for Real-World Product Complexity

documents.t: AVC (Advanced Variant Configuration) is SAP‚Äôs modern replacement for LO-VC ‚Äî bringing a rule-based engine, configuration models, and dependency management into the S/4HANA stack. However: You can‚Äôt use variant functions anymore. Business logic needs to be expressed inside the model, which quickly becomes unmanageable. Master data‚Äìdriven restrictions or cross-characteristic rules require workarounds or duplication. Advanced scenarios (e.g. order dressing, technical validations, or conditional routing logic) require external logic execution, which AVC does not natively support. mdVC is not a replacement of AVC ‚Äî it is a focused extension layer.
mdVC connects AVC to modern SAP technologies in a controlled and transparent way:

Use Core Data Services (CDS) to define restrictions and characteristic filters based on live SAP master data ‚Äî materials, plants, BOMs, customer info, etc. No more hardcoded values or duplicated data.
Plug in BRF+ rules as part of the configuration process ‚Äî cleanly separated from the model. This allows: Centralized rule management Business-side governance Easy maintenance and version control

For scenarios where decision logic depends on runtime context or complex algorithms, mdVC allows controlled injection of ABAP logic (with pre-defined interfaces). Ideal for: Complex pricing adjustments Rule-based routing Post-configuration validations or enrichments

mdVC was born in the metals industry, where standard variant configuration simply doesn‚Äôt scale. Think of use cases like: Configuring coils or sheets with chemical, mechanical, and dimensional constraints Adjusting routings and BOMs based on plant-specific capabilities Applying customer-specific finishing processes or tolerances Order dressing logic that requires multiple steps and context-aware decisions This is where mdVC shines ‚Äî linking configuration to actual execution logic without burying complexity in the model.

With mdVC you can use: CDS Views for data modeling BRF+ for business rule execution ABAP exits for advanced logic No black-box logic, no framework lock-in It works with AVC, not around it ‚Äî and it's fully extensible using SAP-standard tools. This means standard integrations, such as SAP CPQ, work out of the box ‚Äî with mdVC logic executed as part of the native AVC configuration process. ‚û°Ô∏è Explore the sidebar to learn how mdVC works, how to extend it, and how it‚Äôs been applied in real-world projects.
